steps.title: Pay attention to the dog's size.
steps.content: Pay attention to the dog's size. Being a member of the toy group, the Pug is a smaller dog breed. They tend to weigh around 13–14 pounds (5.9–6.4 kg), standing 11–15 inches (28–38 cm) tall.

steps.title: Look at the tail of the dog.
steps.content: Look at the tail of the dog. A Pug's tail is known for being curled. The tail of a Pug should be curled (preferably double-curled) over the dog's hip tightly. steps.title: Notice the dog's head shape.
steps.content: Notice the dog's head shape. The AKC standards state that a Pug's head shape should be "large, massive, [and] round". steps.content: See if the dog has dark, prominent eyes. Pugs have round, bold eyes. Their eyes are usually a dark color, such as brown. steps.title: Look for small ears that rest atop the dog's head.
steps.content: Look for small ears that rest atop the dog's head. A Pug's ears are either classified as "rose" or "button" type ears. "Rose" ears refer to small, folded ears with edges touching the side of the head. "Button" ears are not as short and are folded more forward rather than on the side of the head. steps.content: See if the dog's build fits the motto multum in parvo ("a lot in a little"). A Pug's build is small, square, and muscular. steps.title: Look at the dog's fur color.
steps.content: Look at the dog's fur color. A Pug is usually an apricot/fawn color or has an entirely black coat. However, Pugs can also be seen in silver, white, or a brindle pattern, which are rarer fur colors. Keep in mind that the AKC only recognizes the fawn and black variations. steps.title: Notice black markings.
steps.content: Notice black markings. If a Pug is of the fawn variety, it will have a black or brownish "mask" around its eyes and muzzle. Fawn Pugs are also seen with black dots on their cheeks and may have a black outline across their back called a "trace". steps.title: Assess how the fur of the dog appears and feels.
steps.content: Assess how the fur of the dog appears and feels. Pugs have sleek fur that sheds consistently. [11] X Research source Their coat is "fine, smooth, soft, short, and glossy", according to the AKC. steps.title: Look for playfulness and an overall attention-seeking, "goofy" personality, especially from younger dogs.
steps.content: Look for playfulness and an overall attention-seeking, "goofy" personality, especially from younger dogs. Pugs love being the center of attention. However, as they age, their energy may slowly decrease. A Pug puppy will be after your attention and may make some trouble. They are curious and love to express their energy, and they are very eager-to-please.

steps.title: Notice if the dog is stubborn.
steps.content: Notice if the dog is stubborn. Pugs don't always have the easiest time listening to what they're told. If the dog likes to do what they want rather than obeying, understand that this breed of dog is naturally stubborn. Giving a Pug proper training can help it to learn how to obey commands with more ease.

steps.title: Watch for a guarding ability.
steps.content: Watch for a guarding ability. Pugs make great watchdogs. They are attentive and will do what they can, despite their small size, to remain loyal and protecting of their owners. This is a desirable trait found in a dog. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Pay attention to the dog's intelligence.
steps.content: Pay attention to the dog's intelligence. Along with being protective, Pugs are smart dogs. They are fairly intelligent, which helps them with their guarding abilities. See how clever the canine is to help determine if they may be a Pug.

steps.title: See if an older dog appears more docile.
steps.content: See if an older dog appears more docile. If the dog is older, rather than being energetic, it may be more willing to follow your directions. As they age, a Pug may become more accepting of human control.

steps.title: Know the differences between a Pug and a Pekingese.
steps.content: Know the differences between a Pug and a Pekingese . A Pekingese can seem exactly like a Pug, especially if it has a short coat. Most Pekingese, however, have quite long fur. Both breeds have wrinkles and flat muzzles, but a Pekingese's tail won't be curled like a Pug's - instead, it hangs over the dog's back. Pekingese can also come in different coat colors than Pugs, though both can be seen in fawn and black. Despite having longer fur, Pekingese don't shed as much as Pugs, but still a moderate amount. [14] X Research source

steps.title: See how French Bulldogs and Pugs differ.
steps.content: See how French Bulldogs and Pugs differ. French Bulldogs are another popular breed with wrinkles and a flat muzzle. They are slightly bigger than Pugs (and therefore not a member of the toy group) and have short, stubby tails. Their ears are perked, rather than the pug's folded ears. A solid black or tan and black Frenchie may have white markings on the chest or stomach, differentiating it from a Pug. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Understand the differences between Pugs and Bulldogs.
steps.content: Understand the differences between Pugs and Bulldogs . Two stubborn, flat-faced breeds, Pugs and English Bulldogs have a lot in common. For example, both have faces coated with wrinkles. However, Bulldogs have short, stumpy tails, while pugs have longer, curled tails. Bulldogs can come in many more color varieties, such as brown or brown with white markings. Pugs are smaller than Bulldogs, as Bulldogs are members of the non-sporting group. Bulldogs also have different ears than Pugs. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Spot differences between Boston Terriers and Pugs.
steps.content: Spot differences between Boston Terriers and Pugs. These two breeds are roughly equal in size and body structure. However, Boston Terriers usually have perked up ears and stubby tails, and they tend to be black and white, while black Pugs aren't seen with white markings. They also have completely different origins - Boston terriers originate in the United States, while Pugs date back to Ancient China. [17] X Research source

steps.title: Notice how Pugs and Boxers differ.
steps.content: Notice how Pugs and Boxers differ. Boxers are medium-sized dogs and larger than Pugs, but the two both tend to have flat, black muzzles. A Boxer can have either cropped or uncropped ears, along with a natural or docked tail. A Boxer's natural tail is longer than a pug's and isn't curled, while the docked tail is very short. Boxers are usually brown or black in color, but also are seen in white, brindle, and more color variants. Pugs aren't typically seen in a brown coat. [18] X Research source

steps.title: Be aware of how Pugs and Bullmastiffs differ.
steps.content: Be aware of how Pugs and Bullmastiffs differ. Pugs and Bullmastiffs may look a little similar in appearance, but Bullmastiffs are much larger dogs. Pugs are small dogs (generally lap dogs), while Bullmastiffs are large dogs sometimes used for guarding. Bullmastiffs have long tails that don't curl over their backs. Both dogs have wrinkles, but Bullmastiffs have usually larger muzzles. [19] X Research source
